unittitle.value: Adolf Gundersen Oral History Interview of Murray Bookchin

extent.value: in 1 half manuscript box and 1 audio cassette box.

abstract.value: The Adolf Gundersen Oral History Interview of Murray Bookchin consists of a 10-audio cassette interview with political theorist Murray Bookchin by political scientist Adolf G. Gundersen. The interview was conducted over a period of five days from August 22-26 1995. In the interview Bookchin discusses events of his life, his books and the development of his political theory. Murray Bookchin (1921-2006) was a social theorist and political philosopher who is most well-known for his theories on ecology and his role in founding the social ecology movement.

p.value: Identification of item, date; Adolf Gundersen Oral History Interview of Murray Bookchin; TAM 737; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Donated by Adolf G. Gundersen in 2017. The accession number associated with this gift is 2018.007.

Murray Bookchin (1921-2006) was a social theorist and political philosopher. He was raised in New York City, and was involved in organized labor and leftist activism from an early age. In high school Bookchin studied science and mathematics heavily, but later shifted his intellectual interests to political theory.  Although he received some formal education, his education was largely informal and self-directed. He was the author of two dozen books on politics, philosophy, history, and urban affairs as well as ecology. He is most well-known for his theories on ecology and his role in founding the social ecology movement. Bookchin's political ideology shifted many times throughout his life from Marxism, to anarchism, and later to a form of libertarian socialism he called libertarian confederalism.

In the interview Bookchin discusses his early life and the development of his political ideology including description of his work as an electrician assistant, military service, education, and his involvement in both Old Left and New Left activism. He talks at length about, discussing the Enlightenment, Marxism, socialism in Europe, post-moderinist thinkers like Foucault and Derrida, and his theories of social ecology and libertarian confederalism. Bookchin's analysis of political theory is largely tied to conversations about his works, including his books <emph render="italic">Urbanization Without Cities</emph>, <emph render="italic">The Ecology of Freedom</emph>, <emph render="italic">Crisis in Our Cities</emph>, and <emph render="italic">Post-Scarcity Anarchism</emph>.
